These lists are sick and invoke panic. People aren't educated about who is on the sex offender list. Remember the story I posted a few weeks ago about Todd and Amy. Well Todd is on the list and his re-offense rate is next to nothing. In fact, most sex offenders won't re-offend.

This can actually be quite fun. I look through the local sex offender registry pretty regularly to get their faces down pretty well in my head. Then, when I run into one at the groceryy store or Wal-mart or someplace similar I like to ask them loud questions like, "How long has it been since you played with little Johnny?" or "What are you doing to keep from being locked up again for being a pervert?" They usually like to duck their head and leave the store. 
 
 There was one I used to see pretty regularly at the convenience store so I printed his picture. The next time I saw him there I took the picture in the store so I could ask if he knew that they put his picture on that sex offender site. After he left the store the clerk asked me for the picture and taped it on the store window. I haven't seen him there since :)

 The obvious implication is that making parents aware of sexual offenders will undoubtedly promote discrimination and vigilantism when civil authorities are proven unable to contain the actual problem. In regard to criminal records, I believe in full disclosure. For some time, DUI offenders got their names and photos in the local weekend paper. I think they've stopped that practice, but the police blotter being public record does not get the information to anyone other than those who research it.
 
 Again, when it comes to preventing crimes against children, I believe a different set of rules should apply. There is very little, if anything, that I would not do to protect the innocence of a child. I see this as a totally different problem from burglary, robbery, murder, embezzlement, fraud, etc. I see the consequences of low vigilance as being quite catastrophic for the child.

Go to the GBI Sex Offender Registry for Georgia Zip Code 30122.
 
 From the list notice Robert Arthur Merrill and Raymond Carl Ratley.
 
 Go to the Georgia Department of Corrections inmate query and search each of these guys. I used the last name only. Make sure to select "All Offenders, Past and Present" to find released inmates.
 
 Robert Arthur Merrill, born in 1945, was convicted for child molestation and spent 8 years with no eligibilty for parole.
 
 Raymond Carl Ratley, of 1938 vintage, was convicted for child molestation and spent 3 years with no eligibilty for parole.
 
 The list of sex offenders in this zip is long but these are not the guys in this zip code convicted of non-child related cases like like adult rape or even statutory rape where the victims are older children. In regard to criminal records, I believe in full disclosure. For some time, DUI offenders got their names and photos in the local weekend paper. I think they've stopped that practice, but the police blotter being public record does not get the information to anyone other than those who research it.
 
 Again, when it comes to preventing crimes against children, I believe a different set of rules should apply. There is very little, if anything, that I would not do to protect the innocence of a child. I see this as a totally different problem from burglary, robbery, murder, embezzlement, fraud, etc. I see the consequences of low vigilance as being quite catastrophic for the child.
 
 Children are our most valuable resource!

 
 That may be true, but lists only advocate violence and discrimination. Its human nature. People don't know these people's full story's and circumstances. It may all be a misunderstanding, or the person could be going through something horrible. It is very improbable that the offender would reoffend, yet it is probably that someone may get hurt or discriminated against regardless.
